Label: Unique identifier for a grouping of samples or runs
Specimen type used in assay
Enumeration: breath | hand odor | plasma | saliva | skin

Label: Dilution of specimen before test
Measured result. If other, specify result in assay_result_other
Numerical assay readout
Unit of assay_readout
Description of assay readout type
Number of samples in a sample_group used to calculate metrics
Limit of Detection (LOD). The minimum amount or concentration of analyte that can be reliably distinguished from zero.
Notes: Armbruster DA, Pry T. Limit of blank, limit of detection and limit of quantitation. Clin Biochem Rev. 2008 Aug;29 Suppl 1(Suppl 1):S49-52. PMID: 18852857; PMCID: PMC2556583.

Label: Concentration unit for limit_of_detection
ROC-based performance. AUC under ROC curve.
The subjects/patients (and specimen types) included in the study
Number of subject in a cohort (see cohort_id) used to calculate metrics
True Positives (TP). The number of subjects/specimens with true positive test results
False Positives (FP). The number of subjects/specimens with false positive test results
True Negatives (TN). The number of subjects/specimens with true negative test results.
False Negatives (FN). The number of subjects/specimens with false negative test results
The proportion of subjects with the target condition in whom the test is positive; calculated as 100xTP/(TP+FN). Used for comparison with a reference (Gold) standard.
Notes: PCR is Gold standard for COVID-19. For comparison with a non-reference standard use percent agreement metrics.

Label: Percent used to define two-sided confidence interval for clinical sensitivity.
Lower bound of confidence interval for clinical sensitivity.
Upper bound of confidence interval for clinical sensitivity.
The proportion of subjects without the target condition in whom the test is negative; calculated as 100xTN/(FP+TN).
Notes: PCR is Gold standard for COVID-19. For comparison with a non-reference standard use percent agreement metrics.

Label: Percent used to define two-sided confidence interval for clinical specificity.
Lower bound of confidence interval for clinical specificity.
Upper bound of confidence interval for clinical specificity.
The proportion of test positive patients who have the target condition; calculated as 100xTP/(TP+FP)
Percent used to define two-sided confidence interval for positive predicted value.
Lower bound of confidence interval for positive predicted value
Upper bound of confidence interval for positive predicted value
The proportion of test negative patients who do not have the target condition; calculated as 100xTN/(TN+FN)
Percent used to define two-sided confidence interval for negative predicted value.
Lower bound of confidence interval or negative predicted value
Upper bound of confidence interval or negative predicted value
Description of the clinical cutoff
Test is considered positive if assay readout is geater than or equal the clinical_cutoff_min value
Unit of clinical_cutoff_min
